29 Oct 2010

A Visual Rendering of the Term Artisanal

By in category

This week, a great rant on the term Artisanal was posted by the food editor of my new favourite blog Grist.  Here are a few choice words Bonnie Azab Powell had about food products claiming to be “artisanal”:

Artisanal once described something meaningful, honoring the labor of people who make things very skillfully, with their hands. By now, it’s just an emptied-out, hollow marketing term, like “fresh.” And things have gotten absurd.

It’s true. Terms like “organic,” “sustainable,” and “artisanal” have been so abused by food companies that they’re now virtually meaningless.

But then again, sometimes language adds a layer of complexity that gets in the way of our own basic “I know it when I see it” intuition.

They say a picture’s worth a 1000 words. So while everyone’s busy writing up Manifestos on the meaning of artisanal,  I thought it’d be best to show some images of Dawn Woodward from Evelyn’s Crackers that demonstrate her dedication to her craft.

Dawn and Ed describe their crackers as “handcrafted from artisanal, organic ingredients.” No matter how you define artisanal, their crackers fit the bill.

How do I know? Have a look at some photos I snapped at our meeting this morning. These are most definitely living examples of the “I know it when I see it” methodology at work.

These are a true baker’s arms. Notice the burn marks? Someone once asked Dawn if she was a cutter. But these kinds of burns are par for the course when you bake your own crackers. Owners of big cracker factories don’t typically get these. Know what I’m saying?

Dawn is extremely dedicated to her craft. How dedicated you ask? Well, dedicated enough to have wheat, that’s right, wheat tattooed on her back.

At one serendipitous moment at the end of our meeting with Dawn and Ed, the Ritz cracker truck went speeding by. We caught Dawn standing in the foreground with the Ritz truck behind.

You’ve heard of Ritz, that little cracker company owned by Kraft? I think it’d be safe to say their crackers aren’t artisanal in any sense of the word. How can you tell? Just check out the size of their truck. It’s a dead giveaway.

Since ’98, we’ve helped a lot of interesting people do important things. We create relevant communications and useful experiences. Find out more.
